title: James Donaldson (classical scholar)
text:
Sir James Donaldson (26 April 1831 – March 1915) was a <a href="Scottish%20people">Scottish</a> <a href="classical%20scholar">classical scholar</a>, and educational and theological writer.
Life.
Donaldson was born in <a href="Aberdeen">Aberdeen</a> on 26 April 1831. He was educated at <a href="Aberdeen%20Grammar%20School">Aberdeen Grammar School</a>, <a href="Marischal%20College">Marischal College</a>, <a href="Aberdeen">Aberdeen</a>, <a href="New%20College%2C%20London">New College</a>, <a href="London">London</a>, and <a href="Humboldt%20University%20of%20Berlin">Berlin University</a>. In 1854 he was appointed <a href="Rector%20%28ecclesiastical%29">Rector</a> of the <a href="Stirling%20High%20School">Stirling High School</a> where he remained for two years, before leaving for the <a href="Royal%20High%20School%20of%20Edinburgh">Royal High School of Edinburgh</a>, of which he was appointed Rector in 1866.
He was elected a Fellow of the <a href="Royal%20Society%20of%20Edinburgh">Royal Society of Edinburgh</a> in 1867, his proposer being <a href="Alexander%20Keith%20Johnston%20%281804-1871%29">Alexander Keith Johnston</a>.
He became in 1881 Professor of <a href="Humanities">Humanity</a> in the <a href="University%20of%20Aberdeen">University of Aberdeen</a>, and in 1890 <a href="University%20principal">Principal</a> of the <a href="University%20of%20St%20Andrews">University of St Andrews</a> by the Universities (Scotland) Act.
He was <a href="knight">knight</a>ed by <a href="Edward%20VII%20of%20the%20United%20Kingdom">Edward VII</a> in 1907, and was awarded an <a href="Doctor%20of%20Laws">LL.D.</a> by the <a href="University%20of%20Glasgow">University of Glasgow</a> and an <a href="Honorary%20degree">honorary</a> <a href="Doctor%20of%20Divinity">Doctor of Divinity</a> by the <a href="University%20of%20Aberdeen">University of Aberdeen</a> in recognition of his work in Church history.
He died on 9 March 1915. and is buried with his wife in the churchyard of <a href="St%20Andrews%20Cathedral">St Andrews Cathedral</a>. He also has a memorial in the <a href="Church%20of%20St%20John%20the%20Evangelist%2C%20Edinburgh">Church of St John the Evangelist, Edinburgh</a>. He was succeeded in his role as Principal by <a href="Alexander%20Stewart%20%28moderator%29">Very Rev Prof Alexander Stewart</a>, but Stewart died only a few months later.
